text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with indoor barbecued shrimp I mean
there's easy recipes and there's really
easy recipes and then there's this
recipe so what you need to do is get a
pound of large jumbo shrimp that it was
redundant so anyway jumbo shrimp and
what you're looking for they're called
ready to peel so they're deveined but
they still have the shell on which
really is a great product because the
shells gonna give it extra flavor when
we sear it and you know they're due
veined we're gonna put some pepper to
taste you're gonna put some salts a
tablespoon of brown sugar a tablespoon
of lemon juice some ketchup all right
now some kind of chili powder I like to
use about a half a teaspoon of chipotle
just gives it a nice little smoky flavor
he's regular chili powder if you want I
got some cumin in there I'm gonna put in
a little shake of allspice just a pinch
and I'm gonna put about a tablespoon of
oil and we're gonna mix that up well now
you want to make sure these shrimp are
really well coated it's not just enough
to get the nooks you got to get the
crannies and then let that sit for 15
minutes you can let it go a little
longer but the the acid in the marinade
there is going to start to cook the
shrimp in the fridge so don't marinate
these overnight or anything like that so
now let's go over to our preheated dry
saute pan I'm gonna sprinkle some water
in there see how it beads up but the
beads don't like instantly evaporate nor
do they just kind of slowly bubble
that's pretty much what I want I want
hot but not smoking hot and I'm gonna
put in my shrimp now we don't need any
oil in the pan because that little bit
of oil we put in the marinade is enough
and it has the shell to protect it so
what you're looking for here on one side
we're gonna watch that shrimp cook and
kind of turn white about almost halfway
up see right where this the it's been
deveined right halfway point there when
that starts to turn from opaque to white
we're gonna give those a flip and for me
that took about three or four minutes
depends on the size that's why I think
you should use a jumbo shrimp the 16 to
a pound size if you can get them the
smaller shrimp really are gonna cook
before the shells really Sears and gets
that
grilled barbecue you know aspect to it
and then the same thing on the other
side you're gonna wait till the shrimp
looks like it's cooked almost all the
way up cuz these are gonna keep cooking
alright as you take them out of the pan
so if you want them nice and moist and
juicy don't wait til they're completely
firm and totally white
alright so that brown sugar is really
gonna kind of sear on there that's gonna
just give it kind of a smoky sweet taste
inside but you know it's not gonna give
it an off flavor so don't worry about
these getting too Brown you want them to
look kind of charcoal-grilled like on a
regular barbecue and there we go a
little bit of coleslaw I'm gonna pull it
out of a shell with my cute little
cocktail Fork and man that is so
delicious this spiciness and the
barbecue flavor from the shell is very
subtle in the shrimp so it looks really
intense and you know over seasoned and
overpowering inside subtle sweet
delicious moist unbelievable I got a
little bit of a sweet coleslaw there
great contrast with the spicy you know
smoky shrimp and that's it indoor
barbecue you don't have to light that
giant fire with the three pounds of
briquettes you're all gonna use the
thing for five minutes so this is a nice
little way to sear these indoors you can
do it with shrimp that don't have the
shells you just got to be careful not to
overcook them really simple recipe
everybody loves it I gave most of the
ingredients but go to the site get the
rest and as always enjoy
